results.title: Atoms and molecules
results.brief_description: Sir Lawrence Bragg describes and illustrates the structure of atoms and molecules, demonstrates their size and the progressive development of microscopic instruments and techniques, and performs experiments showing the wetting of oil molecules and the Brownian movement. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Atomic physics: an historical approach
results.brief_description: A five part series designed for use in agencies teaching advanced physics. This series traces the development of atomic energy from when John Dalton forwarded his atomic energy theory in 1808. Through reconstruction and interviews, the scientists Dalton, Faraday, Rutherford, Cockcroft, Frisch and Einstein are introduced. Each part of the series is usable independently.

results.title: Atomic energy explained
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Film Producers Guild
results.brief_description: A practical outline of atomic energy and its peaceful applications. Studies the structure of atomic particles and shows how energy can be released from them to produce atomic power. Also illustrates how radio-isotopes are being put to valuable use in modern industry and medicine. No other credits available.

results.title: Atom and agriculture
results.brief_description: The importance, types and principal uses of radio-active isotopes in agricultural research; radio-active cobalt and calcium used to study growth and hereditary characteristics in plants; radio-active carbon-dioxide used to study the chemistry of food production; radio-sulphur used in the study of wool growth; use of radio-active calcium and phosphorous in research work on egg production. No other credits available.

results.title: Atmospheric science
results.creator_credit: Mel Waskin, Joel Marks, Bill Walker Productions and Coronet
results.brief_description: Dramatic cinematography and timelapse photography convey the drama of nature’s spectacular display. ‘Global winds’ demonstrates global circulation and how these movements depend on great convection cells set in motion by differences in temperature. ‘Clouds and precipitation’ looks at how clouds form and vanish and explains the differences between the types of clouds we see. ‘Violent storms’ examines the causes and effects of thunderstorms, thunderheads and tornadoes. Suitable for Upper Primary and Secondary level students.

results.title: Atmosphere in motion
results.creator_credit: William Kay and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explores the causes and effects of atmospheric motion. Time-lapse photography makes the ordinarily slow movement of clouds readily observable and uses experiments to illustrate and explain other atmospheric phenomena.

results.title: Atmosphere and its circulation
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the nature of air, showing its structure, chemical composition, weight and distribution. Its circulation in relation to the Earth, how circulation forms pressure bands and is affected by rotation of the Earth, causing movement or winds; the structure and dynamics of atmosphere are studied with the aid of animated diagrams. No other credits available.

results.title: Atlantic trawler
results.creator_credit: Frank Sainsbury, John Taylor, Great Britain. Ministry of Information and Realist Films
results.brief_description: Life aboard a fishing trawler off the West Coast of England, under arduous and dangerous war-time conditions. Shows the daily life of the crew at sea, consisting of fishing day and night and hauling every three or four hours. Also looks at life on land as women repair nets, clean fish and greet their returning husbands. Tragically, the steam trawler ‘Hondo’ on which this documentary was filmed returned to sea with a different crew and was lost with all hands. Photographed by A. E. Jenkins, Chick Fowle and Cyril Phillips. Sound by Ken Cameron and Jock May. Music by William Alwyn.

results.title: Atlantic Isles
results.brief_description: Compares the life of people in the Shetland Isles, where the climate is extreme, with that of the people of the Channel Isles who enjoy more equable weather. Shetland Isles (Mainland, Unst, Yell, Foula, Lerwick): crofter’s house, vegetable growing, Shetland ponies, weaving, knitting fair-isle woollens, fishing. Channel Isles (Alderney, Guernsey, Sark, Jersey, St Peter Port, St Hellier): tomato growing in glasshouses, potato growing, cattle breeding, historic buildings.
